column9: Poison oak and poison ivy reactions. Tried gutting through the outbreaks with over-the-counter drugs (hydrocortisone, calamine lotion, benadryl, etc.). Finally went to a walk-in clinic, got a shot of steroids, and this Triamcinolone Acetonide cream. The cream was a godsend--no itching, no burning, gradual reduction in swelling, no permanent scarring. Read lots of eczema treatments, which are chronic to my limited knowledge. For acute outbreaks of contact dermatitis or allergic reactions, I would strongly recommend going to a doctor and asking about this treatment.

column2: nrg2brn, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Having suffered for nearly forty years with eczema and tried countless ointments, tablets and other prescriptions, I was totally wowed by the effectiveness of this drug.  Growing up, I had eczema in the joint areas (inner elbows, back of legs, back of neck).  Not understanding my skin's sensitivity, my parents had me washing dishes and doing laundry during my teens which worsened the problem.  After college, I upgraded my skin care to Eucerin cream and Cetaphil "soap" which are great OTC products.  Sun & Earth make great skin-safe laundry and cleaning products.Now my issue is the scarring and seasonal flare ups, but this medicine gets right in there and calms and actually smooths my skin.  Only my hands are affected now, so I use gloves etc.I know that my skin will never be normal, but using this medicine helps it look normal.  I must say that I had been going to a doctor who was prescribing the normal stuff year after year (Lidex, Atarax, Topicort, etc).  Don't get stuck in that rut cycle.  See another doctor -- someone who wants to heal you/make you feel pretty and not just contain the discomfort.

column2: kjwike, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have severe eczema - starting in childhood and I am now 25 and still suffer from it.  I was put on triamcinolone steroid cream when I was a child which worked, what I thought was, wonders.  The itching red spots disappeared within days, and my mother and I were very excited.  My mother specifically asked if there were any side effects to be worried about from a steroid especially thinning of the skin - and we were told not to worry. I have always been fit and never over weight, but my sophomore year of high school I began showing stretch marks on my inner thighs...the only explanation I have is the steroid cream did indeed thin my skin so much over the years that when I grew my skin didn't have enough elasticity left to stretch without stretch marks.  The problem with steroid cream is that it works, and it works very well, but there are consequences.  I would not recommend using it in children unless it is only for a short period of time, or on a small area of skin. (I was applying cream over basically all of my body)  I hope this helps, and good luck to everyone!

column2: Rowellcat79, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed this cream b/c I had a horribly itchy rash on my legs, that would not go away. After no cause could be found, ti was determined that it was possibly a minor staph infection. This medication worked very, very well for me. Not only did it relieve the itching, but within days began to clear the condition. However, it did not work immediately, as I had hoped, so patience was needed. Further, I was told that this medicine has a tendency to 'thin' ther skin and cause spider veins, so the cream should ONLY be placed on the area that is bothersome, even if it means applying to each little bump. I was very happy with the effectiveness of this medicine.
